fact: Yaks are herbivores.  They eat mainly grasses but will also munch on herbs, flowers, shrubs, and moss.
Wild yaks weigh more than domestic yaks.  A wild yak bull can weigh over 2200 pounds (1000 kg).
Yaks have horns that can reach 30 inches long in males and 20 inches long in females.
Yak poop is often used as fuel.  However, it produces black carbon, which is reportedly the second-leading cause of global warming.
Yak females carry babies for about 9 months before being born.
Yaks are native to the Himalayas in Asia.
Yaks live mostly in elevations of 14,000-20,000 feet.
Female yaks usually give birth once every other year.
Yaks are 5-7 feet tall.
Yaks have heavy coats of hair to keep warm in their cold habitats.
Yaks are related to cows, water buffalo, and bison.
Yaks are work animals are are used to carry people, carts, packs, and plows.
Yaks are ungulates; that means they are large hooved mammals.
Yak racing is a form of entertainment in Tibet and Karakorum.
Yaks eat the same food as cattle but need half the amount of food a cow eats to survive.
Yaks live in herds of up to 100 but are usually found in herds of 10-30.  Some males live in bachelor groups; others may live alone.
Wild yaks are listed as a vulnerable population.  Their numbers are decreasing.
Yaks live at the highest elevation of any animal.
A yak lifespan is typically 15-20 years.
The top speed of a yak is 25 miles per hour.
Yaks can live in temperatures as low as -40 degrees Fahrenheit.
Yaks are typically black or dark brown in color; some can be cream.
Tibetan butter tea is a traditional drink in Tibet.  It has a base of black tea and includes yak butter, yak milk, and salt.
